title: Exclusive: British sports venues could be given the power to disrupt drone attacks under new Government plans
text:
Operators of sports venues in Britain could be given the power to disrupt a drone attack under plans being considered by the Government.

Nine months after a Daily Telegraph investigation found Premier League clubs and other event organisers were as ill-equipped to combat the threat posed by drones as Gatwick Airport had been over Christmas, ministers are to discuss expanding the list of those authorised to take them out of the sky.

This is currently limited to the police and armed forces but the Home Office’s UK Counter-Unmanned Aircraft Strategy, published this week, confirmed the same powers could be bestowed upon “private sector employees responsible for safety and security in a variety of locations”, such as “crowded open-air public spaces”.

A Government spokesperson last night confirmed that would include sports venues, which the Telegraph revealed in January had yet to invest in technology designed to stop a terrorist atrocity or other serious incident, despite it being available before the intrusion that grounded flights for three days at the country’s second-busiest airport.

Those who could afford it were warned they could soon face their own “Gatwick moment”, or worse, if they failed to join the airport and Heathrow by purchasing detection, tracking and other countermeasures.
description: Operators of sports venues in Britain could be given the power to disrupt a drone attack under plans being considered by the Government.
